data.title: FRENCH BATTLESHIP RICHELIEU IN AMERICA

fighting under General de Gaulle.

Actually all French ships not scut-

tled at Toulon are now in Allied

hands.

Vice-Admiral Fenard said that the

battleship Jean Bart, smashed at

Casablanca during the Allied landing

in North Africa, could be salvaged,

but it was improbable that she would

fight in this war because of the im-

practicability of manufacturing 15in

guns.

Storm

The Richelieu and the ships with

her reached port after having dodged

submarines and ridden out the worst

Atlantic storm the crews had experi-

enced.

Only three of the Richelieu's en-

gines were working, and at the stern

a temporary hull of big timbers had

been built over the 40ft. rent in the

side made by British depth charges

and torpedoes at Dakar in 1940.

United States destroyers es-

corted the Richelieu as she was

forced by the storm to travel at

a slow speed.

The crew were very excited and

happy when they saw the Statue of

Liberty loom up through a heavy

fog at the journey's end.

Captain Marcel Deramond said that

their coming would show the Ameri

can people that France still has a

navy and sailors anxious and eager

to fight.

On the fifth day out the radio

warned that submarines were dead

ahead. .

'We abruptly, and temporarily

changed our course and saw no trace

of the enemy,' said Captain Dera-

mond.

Bearn

A United Press correspondent ac-

companying the Richelieu says that

the transfer is the first positive step

to outfit a major unit of the French

Navy for use against the enemy.

The eighteen-ktnot carrier Bearn

which is at Martinique may be re-

fitted in the United States.

The refitting in all cases will

necessitate the removal of the

elegant woodwork which adorns

all French ships.

Richelieu is 794ft. long, 'has

eight 15in. guns, 15 6 -in. guns and

36 anti-aircraft guns. She has

four aircraft, carries a crew of

1670.

Completed in 1940 she was then

the most modern and formidable

capital ship in the- world.

On July 11, 1940, Prime Minister

Churchill announcing the damaging

of the ship at Dakar, said that the

Cabinet 'with aching hearts but

with clear vision unanimously felt

bound to take measures to prevent

the French fleet from felling into

German hands.'

Four alternatives were offered to

the French admirals and were re-

jected:

1. That the ships should sail to a

British port with a guarantee that

the crews would be repatriated;

2. That they sail to the French

West Indies, be demilitarised or en-

trusted to U.S.A.;

3. That they be demilitarised at

Dakar, or

4. That they be sunk by the

French themselves.
